| disciples as Peter, Andrew, Matthew, Thomas, Philip, John, James, Bartholomew,
| and Simon" shrine = St. Peter's Basilica attributes = Keys of Heaven,

| Apostle, holding a book or scroll. Iconographically, he is depicted with a
| bushy white beard and white hair. patronage = Patronage list
}} 'Saint Peter' (, ; died AD 64/67 ), also known as 'Simon
Peter', was an early Christian leader, one of the Twelve Apostles of Jesus
Christ according to the New Testament and Christian tradition, and the very
first Bishop. Peter is featured prominently in the New Testament Gospels and the
Acts of the Apostles and is venerated as a Saint and the first Pope by the
Catholic Church, the Eastern Orthodox Church, and
Oriental Orthodoxy. The son of John or of Jonah or
Jona, King James Bible (KJB), DouayâRheims Bible (D-R) he was from the
village of Bethsaida in the province of Galilee or Gaulanitis. His brother
Andrew was also an apostle. Peter is venerated in multiple churches and is
regarded as the Catholic Church's first pope. He is credited with establishing
the church in Antioch and presiding for seven years as the leader of that city's
Christian community. Either in person or via epistle, his words
reached Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia Minor and Bithynia where they were
received by scattered communities of believers: Jews, Hebrew Christians and Gentiles. [http://bible.cc/1_peter/1-
1.htm] Online Parallel Bible Project - 1 Peter 1:1 Peter then went to Rome
where in the second year of Emperor Claudius Germanicus, it is claimed, he
overthrew the sorcerer Simon Magus, "Simon Magus," F. L., Cross, The Oxford
Dictionary of the Christian Church, Oxford University Press, 1983, p.
1277. was later freed by his Guardian Angel from prison, and held the
Cathedral Chair for 25 years. "Peter, St. " F. L., Cross,
The Oxford Dictionary of the Christian Church, Oxford University Press,
2005

Two general epistles are ascribed to Peter, although the majority of Biblical
scholarship rejects the Petric authorship of both. Dale Martin 2009
(lecture). [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XJ9Gt_R5a-k "24. Apocalyptic and
Accommodation"]. Yale University. Accessed July 22, 2013. Brown,
Raymond E., Introduction to the New Testament, Anchor Bible, 1997, ISBN 0-385-24767-
2. p. 767. The Gospel of Mark was traditionally thought to show the
influence of Peter's preaching and eyewitness memories. Several other books
bearing his nameâthe Acts of Peter, Gospel of Peter, Preaching of Peter,
Apocalypse of Peter, and Judgment of Peterâare rejected by the Catholic Church
as Apocryphal. Thomas Patrick Halton, [http://books.google.ca/bo-
oks?id=uqzY1zBtKg0C&pg=PA5&dq=%22I+simon+Peter%22+%22Ones+who+are+scattered%22&-
lr=&num=100&as_brr=3#v=onepage&q=%22I%20simon%20Peter%22%20%22Ones%20who%20are%-
20scattered%22&f=false On Illustrious Men], v. 100, CUA Press, 1999, pp 5â7 ISBN
0-8132-0100-4. The [http://www.newadvent.org/fathers/2708.htm Early
Church Fathers] Chapter 1 According to New Testament accounts, Peter was
one of twelve apostles chosen by Jesus from his first disciples. Originally a
fisherman, he was assigned a leadership role and was with Jesus during events
witnessed by only a few apostles, such as the Transfiguration. According to the New Testament, Peter confessed Jesus as the
Messiah, New Testament: Gospel of Matthew 16:16 was part of Jesus'
inner circle, New Testament: Gospel of Mark 5:37 walked on
water, New Testament: Gospel of Matthew 14:29 denied Jesus, New
Testament: Gospel of Luke 9:28, Luke 22:54-62 and preached on the day of
Pentecost. New Testament: Acts of the Apostles 2:14-40

Peter is said to have been crucified under Emperor Nero Augustus Caesar. It is
traditionally held that he was crucified upside down at his own request, since
he saw himself unworthy to be crucified in the same way as Jesus Christ.
Catholic tradition holds that Saint Peter's site of crucifixion is located in
the Clementine Chapel, while his mortal bones and remains are contained in the
underground Confessio of St. Peter's Basilica, where Pope Paul VI announced the
excavated discovery of a first-century Roman cemetery in 1968. Every June 29
since 1736, a statue of Saint Peter has been crowned in St. Peter's Basilica
with a papal tiara, ring of the fisherman, and papal vestments, as part of the
Feast of Saints Peter and Paul.
